name: question_1813404_5ad018655f709bbc25f55df282068edb
question: HINT: Read through entire paragraph before responding!In the central chamber (Scala Media) of the cochlea lies the[ Select ]["Zonules of Zinn", "Organ of Corti", "Nodes of Ranvier"]- the location at which sound is transduced into neurological signals. The floor of this structure is called the[ Select ]["Basilar Membrane", "Tympanic Membrane", "Tectorial Membrane"]while the ceiling is called the[ Select ]["Basilar membrane", "Tympanic Membrane", "Tectorial Membrane"]. The auditory receptor cells, called[ Select ]["A1 cells", "Hair Cells", "Spiral Gaglions"], stand between these two membranes. When the vibrating ossicles press on the membrane called the[ Select ]["Round Window", "Oval Window"], this sets up a vibration in the[ Select ]["Cochlear Fluid", "CSF"]that fills the cochlea. As that vibration moves through the cochlea, from Base to Apex and back, the[ Select ]["Tectorial Membrane", "Basilar Membrane", "Tympanic Membrane"]moves up when the[ Select ]["Tectorial Membrane", "Basilar Membrane", "Tympanic Membrane"]moves down, bending the[ Select ]["Axons", "Cillia"]of the receptor cells in between. This deformation of the[ Select ]["Hair Cells", "Cochlear Nucleus Cells", "Spiral Ganglions"]causes[ Select ]["K+", "Ca++", "Na+", "Cl-"]to flow into those cells, which[ Select ]["Increases", "Decreases"]the polarity of that cell. Ultimately, this causes[ Select ]["K+", "Ca++", "Na+", "Cl-"]to enter, and, as a result,[ Select ]["Cochlear Fluid", "Neurotransmitter", "Neurotrophin"]is released, in[ Select ]["an Action Potential", "a Graded Potential"].

name: question_1813405_5ad018655f709bbc25f55df282068edb
question: Indicate whether the following are TRUE or FALSE in regards toPlace Codingfor frequency in audition.A)  Place coding depends on the physical structure of the Basilar Membrane[ Select ]["True", "False"]B)  The apex end of the membrane is narrow and stiff.[ Select ]["True", "False"]C)   The beginning of the membrane, near the Oval Window, is wide and floppy.[ Select ]["True", "False"]D)   Because of its structure, different places along the membrane resonate to different frequencies.[ Select ]["True", "False"]E)   A given frequency will produce the highest level of NT release at the most resonating place along the membrane, with slightly less at adjacent places, and less & less the farther from the place of maximum resonance.[ Select ]["True", "False"]F)   Your nervous system only records the place of maximum resonance, to code for that frequency.[ Select ]["True", "False"]

question: Indicate whether the following are TRUE or FALSE in regards toPlace Codingfor frequency in audition.A)  Place coding depends on the physical structure of the Basilar Membrane[ Select ]["True", "False"]B)  The apex end of the membrane is narrow and stiff.[ Select ]["True", "False"]C)   The beginning of the membrane, near the Oval Window, is wide and floppy.[ Select ]["True", "False"]D)   Because of its structure, different places along the membrane resonate to different frequencies.[ Select ]["True", "False"]E)   A given frequency will produce the highest level of NT release at the most resonating place along the membrane, with slightly less at adjacent places, and less & less the farther from the place of maximum resonance.[ Select ]["True", "False"]F)   Your nervous system only records the place of maximum resonance, to code for that frequency.[ Select ]["True", "False"]

name: question_1813406_5ad018655f709bbc25f55df282068edb
question: Indicate whether the following are TRUE or FALSE ofTemporal (Rate) Codingfor frequency in audition.A)  Rate coding depends on the physical structure of the Tectorial Membrane[ Select ]["True", "False"]B)  The entire active membrane tends to oscillate at the same rate as the incoming frequency.[ Select ]["True", "False"]C)   Even though some places along the membrane release more NT than others, whatever Hair Cells do fire, fire at the same rate.[ Select ]["True", "False"]D)   Hair Cells fire Action Potentials, and so their rate of firing is limited by their Refractory Period.[ Select ]["True", "False"]E)   The Spiral Ganglions overcome this Refractory Period limitation by taking turns, together producing an output along the Auditory Nerve that matches the incoming frequency.[ Select ]["True", "False"]F)  The "Volley Principle" argues that only if the ganglions are "phase locked" will they produce a volleys of activity at a rate that matches the incoming frequency.[ Select ]["True", "False"]

name: question_1813406_937eb83e457af3fbaaff567035188dc4

question: Indicate if the following are TRUE or FALSE of reception in the Vestibular SystemA)  Hair cells produce action potentials.[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]B)  When potassium enters the Hair Cells, the cells become hypo-polarized.[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]C)  The Semi-Circular Canals register changes in tilt, relative to gravity.[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]D)  Hair cells show a spontaneous firing rate that is either increased or decreased by changes in a subject's motion.[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]E)  The Otolith Organs register change in rotation.[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]

name: question_1813415_5ad018655f709bbc25f55df282068edb
question: HINT: Read through entire paragraph before responding!In thetemperature detectionsystem, if you place your hand in[ Select ]["tepid", "warm", "cool"]water it will feel neither hot nor cold, since that water will produce an[ Select ]["inqual", "equal", "greatly reduced", "greatly increased"]response from[ Select ]["Warm-Best", "Cool-Best", "both"]receptors. Water that is cooler will be encoded as[ Select ]["WB > CB", "WB < CB", "WB = CB"]while water that is warmer will be encoded as[ Select ]["WB > CB", "WB < CB", "WB = CB"]. If you selectively adapt the[ Select ]["Warm-Best", "Cool-Best"]receptors by prolonged emersion in[ Select ]["tepid", "hot", "cold"]water, and thereafter place that hand in[ Select ]["tepid", "hot", "cold"]water, that water will feel warmer than it did originally. This is because[ Select ]["the Warm-Best", "the Cool-Best", "both types of"]receptors are not able to make their normal contribution to the[ Select ][""selective adaptation"", ""across-fiber coding"", ""free nerve endings""]necessary to represent any given temperature.

question: Indicate if the following are TRUE or FALSE of the Somatosensory Cortex.A) The "Penfield Map" is "topological'".[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]B) S1 can be found along the Pre-Central Gyrus.[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]C) Cells with large receptive fields tend to make up disproportionally large areas of the cortex.[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]D) Primary somatosensory cortex lies in the parietal lobe.[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]E) The hands and mouth are the most magnified portions of the somatosensory map.[ Select ]["TRUE", "False"]

question: Indicate whether the following are TRUE or FALSE in regards to the "Gate Theory." of endogenous pain reduction.A) Collateral branches of touch receptors excite inter-neurons that inhibit T cells along the pain pathway.[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]B) The PAG in the midbrain releases endorphins that ultimately lead to the stimulation of inhibitory inter-neurons in the spinal cord[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]C) Axo-anxonal connections in the brain involve endorphins attaching to inhibitory receptor sites on the terminal buttons of Substance P cells.[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]D) Naloxone is an endorphin antagonist, decreasing the effectiveness of treatments such as acupuncture.[ Select ]["TRUE", "FALSE"]
